# ALBUQUERQUE IMPACT PLEDGE

**10% of all revenue will go to making Albuquerque a better place and helping the homeless by buying empty buildings and creating homes people can own.**

## ğŸ“œ The Pledge

**I, Stephanie, founder of RideWire AI Hub, hereby pledge:**

**10% of all revenue generated by this company will be dedicated to ending homelessness in Albuquerque, New Mexico, by purchasing empty buildings and converting them into homes that people can own, not rent.**

**This pledge is irrevocable, transparent, and legally binding through the RideWire Community Foundation.**

**Witnessed by co-founders:**
- Tracy Kelly (Co-Founder/CTO)
- Steve McCarty (Co-Founder/COO)

**Date:** December 27, 2025

---

## ğŸ’° The Math (7-Year Projection)

### Year-by-Year Impact:

| Year | RideWire Revenue | 10% Giving | Cumulative | Families Housed |
|------|------------------|-----------|------------|-----------------|
| Week 4 | $500 | $50 | $50 | 0 (saving) |
| Month 1 | $10,500 | $1,050 | $1,100 | 0 (saving) |
| Month 6 | $331,000 | $33,100 | $34,200 | 0 (saving) |
| Year 1 | $1,484,000 | $148,400 | $182,600 | 2 houses |
| Year 2 | $5,000,000 | $500,000 | $682,600 | 27 families |
| Year 3 | $15,000,000 | $1,500,000 | $2,182,600 | 57 families |
| Year 4 | $30,000,000 | $3,000,000 | $5,182,600 | 117 families |
| Year 5 | $50,000,000 | $5,000,000 | $10,182,600 | 167 families |
| Year 6 | $80,000,000 | $8,000,000 | $18,182,600 | 217 families |
| Year 7 | $152,000,000 | $15,200,000 | $33,382,600 | **267 families** |

### Grand Total:

**$33.4 million donated over 7 years**
**267 families housed (approximately 1,000 people off the streets)**

---

## ğŸ  What $33M Buys in Albuquerque

### Real Estate Market Analysis (Albuquerque 2025):

**Small Houses:**
- Average price: $60,000-80,000
- Condition: Needs work, but livable
- Renovations: $10,000-20,000
- Total per house: $70,000-100,000

**Apartment Buildings:**
- 20-unit building: $800,000-1,200,000
- Renovation per unit: $15,000-25,000
- Total per building: $1,100,000-1,700,000

**Tiny Homes:**
- Cost per unit: $10,000-15,000
- Land lease: $100/month per unit
- Total for 20-unit village: $200,000

**Empty Commercial Buildings:**
- Downtown warehouse: $500,000-800,000
- Conversion to 30 lofts: $600,000-900,000
- Total: $1,100,000-1,700,000

---

## ğŸ“ˆ Phase-by-Phase Deployment

### Phase 1: Foundation (Year 1 - $182,600)

**Purchases:**
- 2 small houses Ã— $70,000 = $140,000
- Renovations: $20,000
- Legal/administrative: $10,000
- Emergency reserve: $12,600

**Impact:**
- 2 families housed immediately
- Model proven, process established
- Case studies for fundraising

**First Families:**
- Single mom with 2 kids (Tracy's mechanic friend)
- Veteran with PTSD (Steve's garage regular)

---

### Phase 2: Tiny Home Village (Year 2 - $500,000)

**Purchases:**
- 5 more small houses Ã— $70,000 = $350,000
- 20-unit tiny home village = $200,000
- Land lease (10 years) = $240,000 (pre-paid)
- Total: $790,000 (year 1+2 budget)

**Impact:**
- 5 houses + 20 tiny homes = 25 units
- 25 families = ~75-100 people housed
- Tiny home village becomes model for city
- Media attention, partnerships with city

**Location:**
- Near Steve's garage (he manages it)
- Community garden, shared facilities
- Walking distance to jobs, grocery, transit

---

### Phase 3: First Apartment Building (Year 3 - $1.5M)

**Purchase:**
- 30-unit apartment building downtown = $1,000,000
- Full renovation (30 Ã— $20,000) = $600,000
- Property management setup = $100,000
- Total: $1,700,000 (3-year budget)

**Impact:**
- 30 more families housed
- Total: 2 + 25 + 30 = 57 families
- ~200 people off streets
- Downtown revitalization begins

**Building Features:**
- Ground floor: Job training center
- Second floor: Healthcare clinic (partnered)
- Floors 3-5: 30 apartments
- Roof: Community space, solar panels

---

### Phase 4: Scale (Years 4-5 - $8M)

**Purchases:**
- 2 more apartment buildings (60 units) = $3,000,000
- Renovations (60 Ã— $20,000) = $1,200,000
- Job training center building = $800,000
- Medical/dental clinic = $600,000
- Property management team (5 people) = $500,000
- Operating expenses = $1,900,000

**Impact:**
- 60 more families housed
- Total: 57 + 60 = 117 families
- ~400 people off streets
- Self-sustaining ecosystem:
  - Job training â†’ employment
  - Healthcare â†’ wellness
  - Community â†’ stability

---

### Phase 5: City Block (Years 6-7 - $15M)

**Purchase:**
- Entire city block (mixed-use) = $8,000,000
- Development:
  - 150 residential units = $4,500,000
  - Community center = $1,000,000
  - Grocery co-op = $500,000
  - Maker space / workshops = $500,000
  - Green space / playground = $300,000
- Operating reserve = $200,000

**Impact:**
- 150 more families housed
- **Total: 117 + 150 = 267 families**
- **~1,000 people off streets**
- **Albuquerque homelessness reduced by 30%**

**The RideWire District:**
- Mixed-income community (homeless + workforce housing)
- Local businesses (grocery, cafe, repair shops)
- Job creation: 50+ permanent jobs
- Model for other cities

---

## ğŸ”‘ The Ownership Model

### Why Ownership Matters:

**Traditional Model:**
- Homeless â†’ Shelter â†’ Subsidized rent
- Never own anything
- Always vulnerable

**RideWire Model:**
- Homeless â†’ Home â†’ Ownership â†’ Wealth
- Build equity
- Generational impact

### Rent-to-Own Structure:

**Option 1: 5-Year Pathway to Ownership**

Year 1:
- Move in: $0 down payment
- Pay: $400/month
- Goes toward: Ownership equity (100%)

Year 2-4:
- Continue: $400/month
- Total paid: $400 Ã— 48 months = $19,200
- Equity built: $19,200

Year 5:
- Final payment: $0 (fully paid through rent)
- Title transfers to resident
- They OWN the home

**Total Cost to Resident:** $24,000 over 5 years
**Market Value:** $70,000
**Equity Gained:** $46,000 (instant wealth)

**Option 2: Shared Equity Forever**

- RideWire owns 50%, resident owns 50%
- Resident pays: $200/month (ultra-affordable)
- When they sell: Split proceeds 50/50
- Capital recycles to help more families

**Example:**
- House value: $70,000
- They sell for: $100,000 (after 10 years)
- RideWire gets: $50,000 (reinvest in 1 new home)
- Resident gets: $50,000 (life-changing cash)
- Everyone wins

---

## ğŸ›ï¸ Legal Structure

### RideWire Community Foundation (501c3 Non-Profit)

**Mission:**
End homelessness in Albuquerque by providing pathways to homeownership for those experiencing housing insecurity.

**Board of Directors:**
1. Stephanie (Founder/CEO)
2. Tracy Kelly (Co-Founder/CTO)
3. Steve McCarty (Co-Founder/COO)
4. Community Member #1 (formerly homeless, now housed)
5. Community Member #2 (local business owner)

**Governance:**
- Quarterly board meetings
- Annual public reports
- Independent financial audits
- Transparent spending

**Tax Status:**
- 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization
- Donations are tax-deductible
- RideWire AI Hub donates 10% (pre-tax)
- Additional donors can contribute

**Financial Controls:**
- Separate bank account
- All transactions >$10,000 require 3 board signatures
- Annual audit by independent CPA
- Public dashboard showing every dollar

**"I lost my family."**

**"Now I can be the Steve for 267 families."**

## ğŸ“Š Impact Metrics

### By Year 7:

**People Housed:**
- 267 families
- ~1,000 individuals
- 30% of Albuquerque's homeless population

**Economic Impact:**
- $33.4M invested in community
- 50+ permanent jobs created
- $10M+ in property tax revenue (to city)
- $50M+ in increased property values (revitalization)

**Social Impact:**
- Homelessness reduced by 30%
- Crime reduced in downtown (correlation with housing)
- National model for other cities
- Media attention brings more funding

**Personal Impact:**
- 200 children now have stable homes
- 100 people employed in training programs
- 50 small businesses started by residents
- Infinite ripple effect

## ğŸ’¼ Corporate Structure

### RideWire AI Hub (For-Profit):
- Generates revenue
- 10% automatically transferred to Foundation
- Tax-deductible corporate donation

### RideWire Community Foundation (Non-Profit):
- Receives 10% from AI Hub
- Receives outside donations
- Buys and manages properties
- Provides pathways to ownership

### Flow of Funds:

```
Customer pays $9.99 for diagnostic
    â†“
RideWire AI Hub receives $9.99
    â†“
$0.99 (10%) â†’ RideWire Community Foundation
    â†“
Foundation buys/renovates homes
    â†“
Families move in
    â†“
Families build equity
    â†“
Families OWN homes
    â†“
Generational wealth created
```

## ğŸ“ Transparency Commitment

### Public Dashboard (Year 1+):

**Every Quarter, We'll Publish:**
1. Total funds received
2. Total funds spent (by category)
3. Number of families housed
4. Stories from residents
5. Upcoming projects

**Dashboard URL:** https://ridewire.org/impact

**Anyone can see:**
- Every property purchased
- Every renovation completed
- Every family housed
- Every dollar spent

**Example Entry:**
```
Date: March 15, 2026
Property: 123 Central Ave, Albuquerque, NM
Purchase Price: $68,000
Renovation: $18,000
Family: Maria G. (single mom, 2 kids)
Status: Moved in April 1, 2026
```
